definition: to feel attached to/to long for/to love

sentences.english: Internet dating, speed dating and dating agencies are all very popular nowadays.
sentences.chinese: 网恋，闪电恋，婚介所在现今都很流行。

sentences.english: You probably know at least one couple who met online.
sentences.chinese: 你可能至少认识一对通过网恋走到一起的夫妻。

sentences.english: This kind of situation is not uncommon in the world of online dating.
sentences.chinese: 这种情况在当今的网恋中并不少见。

sentences.english: Despite the barrier of distance, their online relationship eventually lead to marriage.
sentences.chinese: 虽然距离很远，他们最终从网恋步入了婚姻殿堂。

sentences.english: At that time I started online dating, and that person is in the Dance inside knowledge.
sentences.chinese: 那个时候我开始网恋了，那个人是在劲舞里认识的。

sentences.english: Online dating sites provide you with a list of people to potentially interact with.
sentences.chinese: 你在网恋网站能与很多人不断地相互的交流。

sentences.english: Online dating can really be amusing.
The fisrt and foremost one is no basis in reality, such as net love.
sentences.chinese: 首当其冲的是缺少现实基础，譬如网恋。

sentences.english: I'm a firm believer that this is the wave of the future.
sentences.chinese: 我十分相信，网恋在将来会很流行的。

sentences.english: Blowing cyberkisses has become a popular pastime in emerging markets too.
sentences.chinese: 鼓吹网恋也成为新兴市场中一种流行娱乐。

sentences.english: People are now able to find their partners on the Internet. This is called online dating.
sentences.chinese: 现在人们在网络上找寻聊伴，这就是所谓的网恋。

sentences.english: A lot of people who are involved in online dating usually ask why such things happen.
sentences.chinese: 很多卷入网恋的人经常会问，为什么会出现那种情况。

sentences.english: "Cyber love" is a beautiful words, and people dream to nice things.
sentences.chinese: “网恋”是一个美丽的词，人们向往美好的东西。

definition: (neologism) to meet sb in real life after forming a relationship online
(romantic) love/CL:個|个[ge4],場|场[chang3]/in love/to have an affair
(slang) to hook up for a one night stand/booty call
love between an older woman and a younger man
to get married soon after meeting (abbr. for 閃電結婚|闪电结婚[shan3 dian4 jie2 hun1]) (neologism c. 2005)
blind date/arranged interview to evaluate a proposed marriage partner (Taiwan pr. [xiang4 qin1])/to be deeply attached to each other
to court/to go steady/to be dating

(lit.) to wither in the light of day/(fig.) the bubble bursts as the reality becomes apparent (esp. of a much-anticipated first meeting with sb)/(of stocks) just as the favorable news is officially published, the stock price falls
to do the splits (gymnastics)/(Tw) two-timing (in romantic relationships)/Taiwan pr. [pi1 tui3]
